levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can expand a single bracket and collect like terms to simplify expressions.
common_errors: Not distributing the -2 to both terms inside the bracket
Sign errors: -2 × -4 = +8 not -8

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Expands double brackets and factorises simple quadratic expressions of the form x² + bx + c.
levels.example_response: Find two numbers that multiply to 6 and add to 5: 2 and 3. x² + 5x + 6 = (x + 2)(x + 3).
common_errors: Finding factors of 6 that add to 6 instead of 5
Not checking by re-expanding

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Factorises difference of two squares, expressions where the coefficient of x² is not 1, and simplifies algebraic fractions.
common_errors: Not recognising the difference of two squares pattern
Cancelling terms instead of factors in the algebraic fraction

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Manipulates algebraic fractions (adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing), factorises where the coefficient of x² is not 1, and uses completing the square. (Higher tier)
common_errors: Adding numerators without finding a common denominator
Not expanding the numerators correctly after multiplying

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Solves one- and two-step linear equations with positive coefficients.
common_errors: Subtracting 3 from only one side
Dividing incorrectly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solves linear equations with the unknown on both sides and equations involving brackets.
common_errors: Not expanding the bracket correctly
Subtracting x terms from the wrong side

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves linear equations with fractional coefficients and solves linear inequalities, representing solutions on a number line.
levels.example_response: Equation: 3x + 2 = 20, 3x = 18, x = 6. Inequality: -7 - 1 < 3x - 2x, -8 < x, so x > -8.
common_errors: Not multiplying every term by 4
Forgetting to reverse the inequality when multiplying/dividing by a negative

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves equations involving algebraic fractions and forms/solves equations from complex real-world and geometric contexts.
common_errors: Not multiplying every term by the common denominator
Not checking solutions in the original equation (to exclude values that make denominators zero)

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Recognises quadratic expressions and can solve quadratic equations when they are already factorised.
common_errors: Giving only one solution
Setting each bracket equal to something other than 0

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solves quadratic equations by factorising, including those requiring rearrangement first.
levels.example_response: Find two numbers that multiply to -15 and add to 2: 5 and -3. (x + 5)(x - 3) = 0. x = -5 or x = 3.
common_errors: Getting the signs wrong on the factors
Not rearranging to get zero on one side before factorising

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves quadratic equations using the quadratic formula and by completing the square, and interprets solutions graphically.
common_errors: Substituting b = 3 incorrectly into -b (getting -3 is correct)
Computing the discriminant incorrectly: b²-4ac = 9-4(2)(-7) = 9+56 = 65

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Uses the discriminant to determine the nature of roots, completes the square to find the vertex form, and solves quadratic equations in applied contexts. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: For what values of k does kx² + 6x + 3 = 0 have no real roots?
levels.example_response: Discriminant < 0: b² - 4ac < 0. 36 - 12k < 0. 12k > 36. k > 3. So for k > 3, the equation has no real roots.
common_errors: Using ≤ 0 instead of < 0 (≤ 0 includes repeated roots)
Not handling k as a parameter correctly

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands that simultaneous equations are two equations that must both be true at the same time, and can solve them graphically.
levels.example_task: From the graph, read the solution of y = 2x + 1 and y = -x + 7.
levels.example_response: The lines cross at (2, 5). So x = 2, y = 5.
common_errors: Reading the intersection point inaccurately from the graph
Not checking the values in both equations

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solves pairs of linear simultaneous equations by elimination or substitution.
levels.example_response: From the second equation: x = y + 1. Substitute into the first: 3(y+1) + 2y = 12. 3y + 3 + 2y = 12. 5y = 9. y = 9/5 = 1.8. x = 2.8.
common_errors: Substituting into the same equation it was rearranged from
Making sign errors during elimination

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves simultaneous equations requiring multiplication of one or both equations before elimination.
common_errors: Multiplying only one equation and not matching coefficients
Arithmetic errors with fractions

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves linear-quadratic simultaneous equation systems and interprets the solutions geometrically. (Higher tier)
levels.example_response: x² - 2x + 1 = 2x - 3. x² - 4x + 4 = 0. (x - 2)² = 0. x = 2 (repeated). y = 2(2) - 3 = 1. The line is tangent to the parabola at (2, 1) — they touch at exactly one point.
common_errors: Not recognising a repeated root as the tangent case
Making errors when rearranging the quadratic

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can continue a sequence given a term-to-term rule and identify whether a sequence is arithmetic (constant difference) or geometric (constant ratio).
levels.example_task: Identify the type of sequence and find the next two terms: 5, 8, 11, 14, ...
levels.example_response: Arithmetic sequence with common difference 3. Next terms: 17, 20.
common_errors: Confusing arithmetic and geometric sequences
Not checking all consecutive differences

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finds the nth term of a linear (arithmetic) sequence and uses it to determine whether a given number is in the sequence.
levels.example_task: Find the nth term of 7, 11, 15, 19, ... Is 99 in this sequence?
levels.example_response: Common difference = 4. nth term = 4n + 3. Is 99 a term? 4n + 3 = 99, 4n = 96, n = 24. Yes, 99 is the 24th term.
common_errors: Computing the zero-th term incorrectly
Not checking n is a positive integer

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Finds the nth term of quadratic sequences (constant second differences) and generates terms from geometric sequence formulae.
levels.example_response: First differences: 4, 6, 8, 10. Second differences: 2 (constant). Since second difference = 2, coefficient of n² is 2/2 = 1. Sequence - n²: 2-1, 6-4, 12-9, 20-16, 30-25 = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 = n. So nth term = n² + n = n(n+1).
common_errors: Not recognising the quadratic pattern from constant second differences
Errors in subtracting n² from the sequence terms

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Works with geometric sequences including sum to infinity, and solves problems requiring sequences in unfamiliar contexts. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: A geometric sequence has first term 6 and common ratio 1/3. Find the sum to infinity.
levels.example_response: S∞ = a/(1-r) = 6/(1-1/3) = 6/(2/3) = 9. This works because |r| < 1, so the terms converge to 0 and the sum converges.
common_errors: Not checking that |r| < 1 (required for convergence)
Computing 1 - 1/3 incorrectly

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can plot a straight line from a table of values and identify whether a line slopes upward or downward.
levels.example_response: Points: (0,-1), (1,1), (2,3), (3,5), (4,7). The line slopes upward.
common_errors: Making substitution errors in the table
Not joining the points with a straight line

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifies gradient and y-intercept from y = mx + c, and finds the equation of a line from a graph.
levels.example_task: A line passes through (0, 3) and (4, 11). Find its equation.
levels.example_response: Gradient = (11-3)/(4-0) = 8/4 = 2. y-intercept = 3. Equation: y = 2x + 3.
common_errors: Computing gradient as run/rise instead of rise/run
Not using (0, 3) to read off the y-intercept directly

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Finds equations of lines from two points or from a point and gradient, identifies parallel lines (same gradient) and perpendicular lines (gradient product = -1).
levels.example_task: Find the equation of the line perpendicular to y = 3x - 2 through (6, 1).
levels.example_response: Perpendicular gradient = -1/3. y - 1 = -1/3(x - 6). y = -x/3 + 2 + 1 = -x/3 + 3.
common_errors: Using gradient 3 instead of -1/3
Not substituting the point correctly

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Interprets gradient as rate of change in context (speed, cost per unit), uses distance-time and velocity-time graphs, and derives line equations in unfamiliar coordinate geometry problems.
levels.example_task: A distance-time graph shows a car travelling at constant speed: after 2 hours it has covered 150 km, after 5 hours it has covered 375 km. Find the speed and the equation relating distance d and time t.
levels.example_response: Speed = gradient = (375-150)/(5-2) = 225/3 = 75 km/h. Using (2, 150): d - 150 = 75(t - 2). d = 75t. This means the car started from the origin (d = 0 when t = 0), consistent with constant speed from rest.
common_errors: Not interpreting gradient as speed in the distance-time context
Computing the gradient from arbitrary points instead of the given coordinates

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Recognises the shapes of basic non-linear graphs: quadratic (U/n-shape), cubic (S-shape), reciprocal (two branches).
levels.example_task: Match each equation to its graph shape: y = x², y = x³, y = 1/x.
levels.example_response: y = x²: U-shaped parabola. y = x³: S-shaped curve through the origin. y = 1/x: two separate curves in opposite corners.
common_errors: Confusing the cubic and quadratic shapes
Not knowing the reciprocal graph has two branches

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Sketches quadratic and cubic graphs, identifying roots, y-intercept and turning points.
levels.example_task: Sketch y = (x-1)(x-3). Label the roots and y-intercept.
levels.example_response: Roots at x = 1 and x = 3. y-intercept: (0)(−3) × ... wait, y(0) = (-1)(-3) = 3. Vertex at x = 2: y = (1)(-1) = -1. So minimum at (2, -1). U-shaped parabola crossing at (1,0) and (3,0), y-intercept at (0,3).
common_errors: Not computing the y-intercept by substituting x = 0
Not finding the turning point

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Recognises, sketches and interprets exponential (y = kˣ), trigonometric (y = sin x, y = cos x) and reciprocal graphs, identifying key features.
levels.example_task: Sketch y = 2ˣ for -3 ≤ x ≤ 3, labelling key features.
levels.example_response: Points: (-3, 1/8), (-2, 1/4), (-1, 1/2), (0, 1), (1, 2), (2, 4), (3, 8). The graph passes through (0,1), increases exponentially for positive x, and approaches 0 (but never reaches it) for negative x. Horizontal asymptote at y = 0.
common_errors: Thinking 2⁰ = 0 instead of 1
Not identifying the asymptote at y = 0

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Sketches transformed graphs and identifies the effect of parameters on graph features. Applies graphical analysis to solve equations and model real-world phenomena. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: Given the graph of y = f(x), sketch y = -f(x + 2) and describe the transformations.
levels.example_response: First, f(x + 2) translates the graph 2 units to the left. Then -f(x + 2) reflects the result in the x-axis. If f had a maximum at (3, 5), the transformed graph has a minimum at (1, -5).
common_errors: Translating right instead of left for f(x + 2)
Applying the transformations in the wrong order

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands function notation f(x) as an instruction: input x, apply the rule, get the output.
common_errors: Thinking f(5) means f × 5
Not substituting correctly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Evaluates composite functions and understands that the order of composition matters.
levels.example_task: f(x) = 2x + 1 and g(x) = x². Find fg(3) and gf(3).
common_errors: Computing fg as f × g rather than f(g(x))
Applying functions in the wrong order

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Finds inverse functions algebraically and understands that the inverse undoes the original function.
levels.example_response: Let y = (2x-3)/5. Rearrange for x: 5y = 2x - 3. 2x = 5y + 3. x = (5y+3)/2. So f⁻¹(x) = (5x+3)/2.
common_errors: Confusing f⁻¹(x) with 1/f(x)
Not swapping x and y correctly

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies graph transformations using function notation (translations, stretches, reflections) and finds composite and inverse functions for complex expressions. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: f(x) = x² + 4x. Express f(x) in the form (x + a)² + b. Hence state the coordinates of the minimum point and find the range of f.
levels.example_response: f(x) = x² + 4x = (x+2)² - 4. Minimum point at (-2, -4). Range: f(x) ≥ -4. Completing the square converts to vertex form, immediately revealing the turning point.
common_errors: Completing the square incorrectly (not subtracting the square of half the coefficient)
Not adjusting the constant term
